title: What was the Roman concept of religion and the sacred, and how did it differ from other civilizations?
first_phrase: This text explores the Roman conception of the sacred. It starts by mentioning how ancient Romans placed their religion not in faith, but experience. It then cites the testimony of Lactantius that the purpose of Roman "religion" was not to seek "truth," but merely to know the ritual. This suggests an active-intense conception of the sacred, exclusive of any fantastic or mythological form of supersensible perception. It symbolizes a Roman counterpart to the realism and intolerance towards the inessential and the subjective. In this context, the Romans see the sacred as mute, essential and not in any form or images.
content: Ma noi sappiamo anche che questi modi di una esperienza mediata e mítologizzata sono inferiori rispetto ad una esperienza diretta e assoluta, cioè senza forme e senza imagini: muta, essenziale. E appunto questo sembra fosse il livello della concezione romana del sacro. In ciò si può ve- dere la coerente controparte sacrale di quel realismo, di quel- l'insofferenza per l'inessenziale, il superfluo, il sentimentale e il soggettivo che nei tempi primi fu sempre romana parola d'ordine sul piano etico, politico e sociale.
last_phrase: To conclude, the ancient Roman conception of the sacred was one of essential and direct experience, without the embellishments of mythology or sentimentality. Their focus on ritual, rather than theology or aesthetics, demonstrated a reverence for the mysterious and powerful forces of the primordial. This view was expressed through the concept of the deity as numen and the practice of invocatory rites, which pervaded all aspects of Roman life.
